title: My Weirdly Good Experience with the Pear Tallow Balm
body:
Okay so I need to talk about this beef tallow balm. The Pear one. Because my skin was being a complete disaster and now it’s… not. I’m sitting here, one beer in, my neighbor’s dog is barking at something, and I’m just thinking about how my face doesn’t hurt anymore. That’s the whole review right there. But I’ll keep going.

My skin type is a mess. It’s like, dry but also gets weird bumps. Not acne, just texture. Angry texture. And in winter? Forget it. Flakes on my cheeks, tight feeling by 3pm, the whole thing. I tried everything from the drugstore. That Cetaphil in the big pump. The La Roche-Posay stuff my friend swore by. Fancy serums in little dropper bottles that cost more than my electric bill. Some made it greasy. Some did nothing. One made it burn. I was about to just give up and live in a humidifier.

Then I saw someone talking about tallow balm for dry, sensitive skin. Beef fat. For your face. I was skeptical. Obviously. It sounds like something your great-grandmother would have used before they invented real stuff. But I was desperate. And curious. The one I got is this Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear, from some small shop on Etsy. Made in France, which felt fancy for beef fat.

## How I Started Using Tallow on My Face

I opened the jar. It looked like frosting. Seriously. Like if you whipped buttercream for a really long time. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. Solid but soft? You scoop a little and it warms up super fast in your fingers.

Smelled like pear. But not like a Jolly Rancher. More like… a pear that’s sitting in a bowl in a sunny kitchen. Or maybe not. I’m bad at smells. It was light. Fresh. Not perfume-y. Just a clean, fruity thing. I was worried it would smell like cooking grease. It doesn’t.

So the first night, I washed my face. Put a tiny bit on my fingertips. Rubbed them together. It felt kind of waxy for a second. Then I just patted it all over. Cheeks, forehead, my weird dry patch near my eyebrow. I braced for it to just sit on top of my skin, all greasy and gross.

But it didn’t.

It sort of… vanished. My skin drank it. Like it was thirsty. That tight, papery feeling I had after washing was just gone. In like, two minutes. My face felt calm. Not shiny. Not sticky. Just normal. But hydrated. I kept touching my cheek because it felt so different. Soft, I guess. But not like a product soft. Like my own skin soft.

I went to bed thinking it was a fluke.

## What This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Does

It wasn’t a fluke. I’ve been using it for… a month? Maybe five weeks. I lost track. Time is fake. Anyway.

My routine is stupid simple now. At night: wash face, tallow balm. Morning: splash with water, maybe a tiny bit more tallow if it’s really cold out. That’s it. I’ve stopped using like, four other products. The best natural moisturizer for my weird combo skin was apparently rendered cow fat. Who knew.

Here’s the specific stuff I noticed. The flakiness on my cheeks? Gone in three days. The rough, sandpapery texture on my forehead? Smoothed out. It didn’t happen overnight, but after a week I could feel it. My skin just felt more… even. Less angry. I get these little red patches sometimes, especially when the heat’s on. They’ve chilled out a lot.

I think the reason it works—and I read this after I bought it, which made me feel smart—is that beef tallow is supposed to be really close to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it absorbs deep instead of just coating the top. It’s not sitting there clogging pores. It’s like it’s giving my skin what it’s actually missing. Especially in this dry winter air that sucks all the moisture out of everything.

I started using it on my hands too. Because why not. I wash my hands a million times a day and they crack at the knuckles. Like, painful cracks. I’ve been putting a dab of this tallow balm on them before bed. Wearing cheap cotton gloves I got at the pharmacy. My hands haven’t looked this okay in years. No cracks. It’s kind of insane. So yeah, I’d say it’s the best tallow for dry, cracked skin on hands. For me, anyway.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks

I don’t want to sound like an infomercial. But the difference is real. My skin barrier feels repaired. It doesn’t freak out as easily. I used to get that stinging feeling when I put anything on it. Now I don’t.

Is it perfect? No. I still have pores. I still get the occasional bump. But the overall landscape is just… calmer. Healthier. It’s not a “glow” or whatever. It’s a lack of problems. My face just exists peacefully now. It’s not a daily struggle.

The jar is lasting forever. You need the tiniest amount. A little scoop the size of a pea is enough for my whole face and neck. I got mine from this little Etsy shop, WhippedTallowCo or something like that. The owner was nice, shipping was quick. It’s just a simple product. No crazy packaging. Just a glass jar with a wooden lid. It feels honest.

## Would I Buy It Again?

I already did. I’m on my second jar. I got one for my mom too for Christmas because she has eczema on her arms and I read tallow can be good for that. She texted me last week saying her elbows haven’t been this smooth in a decade. So that’s a win.

Look. If you’re like me, and your skin is sensitive, dry, reactive, and generally pissed off at modern life… this might help. It’s not magic. But it’s the closest thing I’ve found. It’s simple. It works. My skin is quiet for the first time in my adult life. I don’t know how else to say it.

If you’re curious about trying a tallow balm for dry and sensitive skin, I’d say go for this one. The pear scent is nice. It’s light. It doesn’t smell like a barnyard. It just smells clean and a little sweet. And the balm itself… it just works. It’s become the only thing I reliably use.

Anyway. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s the whole story.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, I think so. For my face, anyway. The science-y reason is that it’s supposed to mimic our skin’s own oils, so it gets absorbed really well instead of just sitting on top. It doesn’t clog my pores. It just feels like it’s fixing the moisture barrier.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not for me. And I’m prone to clogging. It absorbs so fast that it doesn’t leave a greasy layer. It’s not like putting Vaseline on your face. It’s more like giving your skin the building blocks it’s missing.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s hard to describe. It’s not a candy smell. It’s a fresh, light pear scent. Like the fruit, not the flavoring. It’s subtle. Fades pretty quick after you put it on. Mostly you just smell nothing, which I prefer.
